I am still regretting choosing withings over FitBit when I bought 2 scales and 2 watches. I was a happy camper with withings and it's awesome app until Nokia came along and ruined features and functionality in one sweep, offering nothing in return.

Nokia has improved its app with the latest update, and users are starting to acknowledge it, but let's not forget that it is still missing functionality and features that were already present and working in the past; that is: this has been a step forward, but right after 200 steps back, so you are still 199 behind. 
Simply own your massive misstep and give us the old app back, that is he right thing to do. To continue pushing your ridiculous decisions down your customers throats is never going to work. 

Are you going to do the right thing?!?!

title: Don’t you hate bored developers?
text: This app has never been a star, but it did what I needed it to do - report on my activity.  Some developer decided to look busy and “fix” the UI. The new look is annoying. I have this blue block on the top of my page that will not go away. The timeline has been replaced with a “last” activity list. You do something once, it stays there forever. You have to scroll through this entire list to get to your timeline where your activities are listed by day, which is more import than that one time you body surfed two years ago. Then there are programs - the last update automatically joined me into a program that I did not request. Sadly, instead of adding value by increasing integration with other apps, we get bloatware from some body who thinks looks are greater than functionality.

title: Loving it so far
text:
The watch is beautiful!  

I bought the Steel HR to replace other fitness trackers.  I will only buy with long battery life but ran into a few issues with the other brands and since I don’t like my tracker to look like a fitness band, the HR was a clear winner!  The battery has to be charged which I wasn’t so sure about at first but it chargers quickly, usually when I go into the shower and return shortly after the watch is charged.  I did have to buy a second charger however when on vacation as I did not pack the charger.  

I bought the scale to monitor my vitals/weight after quitting smoking and love the tracking of heart rate, sleep and weight to keep myself on top of my health.  I am seeing positive trends and have had no issues!  Although I am not sure of the accuracy of some of the measurements on the scale (bone density, water, etc) I think the trend is very telling to keep on track of making healthy choices!  

Loving everything about the Steel HR and scale combination!  Love that they work together and all info is available at a quick glance of the ap!

title: Weight Enhancement
text: Good app that does not take advantage of what could be possible, specifically with a focus on weight data representation. Weight is most important of course but the graphics could be much better, as well as enhanced graphics just for weight. For example when I look at my weight graph, the weight number is on top of the graph obscuring the graph. The graph itself should be enhanced, perhaps to include deltas. It should be bigger too. I had to put my finger on each day and take screen shots to show a week’s progression and that’s not good. We are doing many things on the app it first we are losing weight. A better emphasis and better graphics and options should be placed on weight. You have the data. It’s ashamed you can’t be more creative and informative with it.

title: Can’t reach customer service.
text: I think my complaint is like many of the others. There is not a number to reach customer service no matter where you work. I’ve had an issue pairing my scale with my iPhone since I put in new batteries to the scale. Done all the information that’s been listed on the app and the website. Still cannot get the two to pair. Extremely frustrating to spend this much money on a scale that does not do what it supposed to do and then there’s no phone number to reach customer service to assist you. As it turns out I was going to purchase another item from this company but considering the issues I’m having now that would not be a wise investment.

title: Enjoying a new experience
text:
I am having fun using the app with my steel HR. I am still learning how to use it. The first time I tried with an elliptical trainer it was great. The first time I tried it on a bicycle it didn’t get my heart rate or distance using gps. I may not have had it in the correct place on my wrist.

I no longer like the app. After an update I think in December it no longer tracks my activities.  I choose bicycling or elliptical and nothing happens. I have to manually add workouts even though I specifically chose that activity to track . I also have problems connecting the app and fitness tracker. Even though the tracker is on my wrist and phone in my hands, the app doesn’t connect. Strange since I can get phone call and text alerts on the tracker. If I restart the phone the app will connect. I don’t think I should need to restart my phone every time I want to see my activity on the app.

title: This app is finally improving.
text:
Latest review: I just reopened health mate, after a long time without using it. The app is looking much more sleek. It stills hasn’t met the quality of its predecessor but it’s sure getting there. I’ll raise my rating from 1 to 3 stars. 

New review: if you have severe vision issues this app is right for you. The 100pt font is visible from the moon. 

Previous review: I love this app. It is clean. It is easy to use. It gets the job done. However there is a minor bug that should be fixed and some tools that the developers should add. The bug: why are all heart rate measures set as a resting measure? Even more now that u can associate heart rate and activities why can't I do it with the app tools themselves as opposed to resort to an external device? Improvements: a GPS tracker for outdoor activities and maybe some stats to compare workouts.

title: An Honest Friend
text: When I step on the scale in the morning, I want to see lower numbers but that is not always the case.  My wife can make me feel better by helping me make excuses but that doesn’t help.  What I need is a motivator, something that shows my progress or lack of.  The graphs help me discover trends in my weight loss and show where I gain.  If I see where I am trending to gain weight I can focus harder and be extra careful to not let down my guard.  The program sends me email reports during the week to show my progress and encourages me to keep up my efforts.  It’s like a good friend who doesn’t make excuses but shows the facts and guides me in the right direction.

title: Doesn’t Sync to Apple Health
text:
Apple Health Syncing is spotty and completely unreliable. I have uninstalled/reinstalled and waited for app updates to fix this issue without luck. What’s the point of this if you can’t connect it with other health data sources on ios? Having the data only in this app is subpar and not worth it. Please fix 

Update: I tried your troubleshooting steps, still does not work. I get data sometimes. This is not an end user issue.

Update: After back and forth with support, it is now clear that the app updating and ios health functionality only happens if you manually open the app to refresh. This is not happening in the background like it once did. Withings is claiming this is an ios limitation however there are other apps that do this in the background so I don’t buy it. I hope they update this functionality to enhance the user experience.

title: Nokia app is crappy compared to old one
text:
We still have the app from Withings on an old iPhone. That is the only one we use now.  If and when that stops pairing with our devices from Withings, we will toss them out and look for something new certainly not Nokia.  I’m certainly not going to pay good money to downgrade to the Nokia app if and when the withings app on our old phone stops working.

I have to agree with the other reviewer – when the Nokia app came out you took 200 steps backwards. Your “fixes” have improved it by maybe 10 steps so we are still 190 steps behind the great Withings app. 

I certainly shouldn’t be your beta tester when I paid good money to have a working app and working devices.  It’s like a bait and switch I paid good money for one thing (Withings app with my scale and blood pressure monitor). Nokia bought it and and took away a large part of its functionality and changed the little they left to a piece of crap.

title: Happy with Scale
text: I’ve owned the Bf analyzer scale for several years now (4).  I now have a 4yr history of my health & body fat % (not just a BMI) and love it!  Even after Nokia buying Withings they have continued to make enhancements to their app which has been nice.  I would have provided 5 stars but my one complaint is that occasionally the scale starts showing my morning weight in kilograms (for no apparent reason?)... I have to reboot the scale and that fixes it, so its annoying, but not a show stopper for me.  The Bf% fluctuates a little, but I own another expensive bf% monitor and the scale is pretty close so its good for monitoring your overall changes.  Beware of cheap scales that claim to give you a bf reading when all they give you is a BMI Calculation.

title: Withings made me an in-home medical device junkie
text:
..and that’s a good thing I think.  Great products. 
A few more products would make my day.  
1. Withings Blood Glucose Meter.  
2. Withings Blood Oximeter. 
3. Withings Gastro Cam.  A wifi enabled product that can be ingested to look for polyps inside one’s colon in the privacy of your own home,  also avoiding the unpleasant clean out stage that most medical clinics demand.    
4. Withings Defibrillator.  Worn on the chest, if the heart stops this handy gadget would bring you back to life.  And when driving, you get a 10-second warning to pull over before any charge is applied so it would be totally safe.  
5. Withings products should adapted to our pets.  For example I’ve tried the BPM on my 2 cats and they seemed okay with it at first but then near the end of each measurement their eyes got really big and I was disappointed that the BPM really didn’t work as well as I had hoped.   
If Withings would just work on the first couple of suggestions I would be happy.  I have other ideas if I could be of service.

title: Blood pressure notes fail to save
text: I’ve been using a wired Withings Blood pressure cuff for several years; reports of Bluetooth connectivity problems make reluctant to upgrade.  I had been pleased with the latest round of changes to the blood pressure monitoring feature, but have just discovered that my notes have not been saved.  If the developers are still reading this, please note that if one takes a reading, makes notes, saves the reading and then hits “check again,” the notes disappear.  I have just lost a lot of information that would have been useful in assessing medication response.  Please also note that the “automatic” feature is not helpful to those with labile blood pressure and heart rate, because one needs to be able to see if any individual reading was skewing the result.

title: Nokia destroys a valuable and important medical tool set
text:
Like others, I have been using Wiithings devices and software to manage my hypertension and weight since 2012. The app has become almost useless for long term tracking of BP and weight measurements. Under Nokia medical grade management tools have become almost useless. No longer can you import you data into Excel for use by your doctor or email your tabular data. There is no graph function to display all your data. The original BP device is not compatible with current software.

How did you screw up such a great collection of products and software?

Addendum: I received a very weak response from “Developer” who suggested I contact Nokia directly which I have done. My hope is that Nokia is serious about restoring the excellent functionality and robustness of the Withings universe of products.

I cannot understand why Nokia bought Withings only to have what were medical grade devices/software (I am a physician) now degraded to unreliable products, presumably mostly software related. 

The first thing you can do to help is to send a letter to all registered users announcing your commitment to restoring the functionality that made these products great.

Update: Clearly Nokia destroyed many valuable features of Withings and cannot seem to correct the problems they have created.

title: Underwhelming
text:
As far as fitness apps are concerned, Health Mate has some annoying flaws. For example, the sleep monitor is extremely inaccurate and is basically useless. In the 6 months or so that I have been using the Steel HR watch along with the Health Mate app, the sleep monitor has never reported my sleep depth better than ‘bad’. It also will report that I’ve had 5 to 8 interruptions per night and sometimes will mark me as being asleep when simply reading a book. 
Be careful installing the app on an iPhone- there are several known conflicts with the Apple Health app. 
Sometimes the app will stop working with the watch which will require a re-install of the app. This has happened 4 times in 6 months. 
Other issues involving how the “GPS” works and records your run or bike make using that part of the app- clunky and awkward. 
All in all my overall opinion is “Meh!”

title: Nice app for my scale
text:
I have been using the Nokia Body+ scale with the app for around 2 weeks now. I am enjoying the features that the HealthMate app offers with being able to add you heart rate, additional exercise, and other health related items. 

I had some minor frustrations after adding my partner, because he very infrequently uses the scale, and then the scale suddenly stopped recognising me. 

I went into the device part of the app and selected myself as the one using the scale, but it still took another day and half a dozen weigh attempts when it finally started recognising me again randomly. 

This was quite frustrating, because I weigh myself twice per day for monitoring purposes and I lost three of my full body analyses because the Body+ scale won’t do an analysis if it doesn’t recognise the user - only records the weight.

There was another day when it randomly didn’t recognise me also. But worked fine on the following use. Having some kind of interactive menu with the scale that allows you to identify yourself if the scale cannot connect or recognise the user would be nice, so when monitoring is occurring no results are lost.

title: Makes staying healthy fun and easy!
text: I really love this app. I first discovered it after purchasing the Withings Smart Body Analyzer. Every morning I step on the scale and it sends my weight, heart rate and BMI right to my IPhone. I added the Blood Pressure monitor and the Pulse O2. The app tracks and controls everything. There’s an old saying “you can’t manage what you don’t measure. The integration of the app and all the Withings/Nokia devices makes management a breeze. And staying healthy is all about keeping an eye on trends. This is where the app excels. For anyone trying to stay in shape, or in my case GET and STAY in shape, I highly recommend this app and integrated products.

title: Will NOT connect to scale
text:
If I could give a ‘zero stars’ I would!  The scale will simply not connect to the IOS app.  I have done everything possible: change batteries, factory reset, reset router, delete/reinstall app. Nothing works.  My iPhone does not find it in Bluetooth, their IOS app will not finish the install process.  AVOID APP AND SCALE AT ALL COSTS!!

UPDATE Feb 19, 2018

After many attempts to correct, with the help of Nokia support, I was able to reconnect the scale.  Unfortunately it lasted about one week and the problem reoccurred!   Shooting for a warranty replacement scale at this point but am not holding my breath.  Seems like a software problem they are simply unable (unwilling maybe?!?) to correct.

title: No way to customize stride and it inaccurately captures levels of sleep
text:
I am using this Nokia/Withing wrist device to capture my activity as well as my sleep cycles.

ACTIVITY:
My sister and I exercise and walk together but our devices show that I am doing more steps than she is. My legs are longer than hers so my device should actually show fewer steps than hers; there is no way to alter length of stride on this device’s settings. 

SLEEP PATTERNS:
Time and again I find it erroneously recording my sleep patterns. Admittedly I regularly go to bed after midnight and wake early to go to the bathroom. Often I return to sleep after this bathroom run until 7:30 or 8:30am but sometimes I experience a period of tossing and turning back in bed. This device intermittently records my time tossing and turning as though I am fully awake and then doesn’t capture any sleep I may actually have after this early morning wake-up. It also intermittently records the time I spend reading before bed or after I awake as light sleep whether I am sitting vertically or repositioning myself horizontally in bed.

title: Could not get my blood pressure...Useless
text:
I am an engineer. I am not an idiot.

I wasted an entire night screwing around with the BPM connect product.

First off you cannot get the app to work unless you opt in to giving these scoundrels your personal data.

Then you go through a painful process to pair the unit to your smart phone. What does a plus (+) sign mean? Where is this documented? 

And then you move on to a vain attempt at obtaining your blood pressure. At this point I am glad it never gave me a reading because I am sure my blood pressure was through the roof!

If you hold the power button for less than one second it does not turn on. If you hold the button three seconds or more it erases all your settings and you have to start over with Bluetooth pairing and entering your wifi network. But you cannot do that until you accept the terms and conditions including allowing the scoundrels to use your personal information again!

Some products need to move into the 21st century and some are best left alone. This is a classic example of the adage “If it works don’t screw with it”

Buy the old and trusted 50 year old blood pressure tester and save yourself the grief.

And to add insult to injury I had a zillion nicknames before I could post this.

title: Sleep no longer syncs
text:
UPDATE: i have replaced my watch with a device from another company and sleep tracking is able to sync to Apple Health & Google Fit via the device’s app. I no longer have Health Mate installed on my phone. 

Prior to Health Mate 5, i never had any issues with Withings pushing data to Google Fit or Apple Health. Now, it seems as if partial data is passed. Weight data gets passed but workouts may take a while to push; sleep data has not been synching for 6 weeks & counting now. I’ll be keeping the app to still utilize my scale but my watch battery is no longer what it used to be; rather than buy a replacement or alternative from Withings, I’ve already decided on another brand as a replacement. Utilizing customer service has been a far worse experience than I expected and would like to escape from this company altogether.

title: ScanWatch
text: Got the watch like 3 days ago, the set up was pretty quick and easy, the watch digital screen froze yesterday so had to do a reset, after that it was good. It’s comfortable to wear especially to the fact you need to keep it on always to get the best out of it. I will suggest for support the option of actually chatting with a live person after dealing with the Bot cause it could not assist me with the information I needed. I have an Apple Watch series 5 that I’m using as a benchmark for the vital stats so next coming days/weeks will determine how effective the watch is. For now, I’m loving it. I’ll be back. The new firmware update 5.2.5 is not yet released in Canada. What’s up with that?

title: Device Desparity
text: Over the years, I have been very happy with your scales. I recently purchased your sleep monitoring system and I am thrilled with it. However, your blood pressure devices are a complete disappointment. They show my pulse accurately but the BP readings are wildly inaccurate compared to two semi-manual devices purchased earlier and readings taken at my physician’s office. I have bought three of your cuffs over the years and I have found that as I have aged that I see my doctor more often and I use the systems in the pharmacy as well. Inevitably, your cuff reads 15 to 20 percent higher. I have taken the latest cuff with me and the disparity is not acceptable. I do not recommend your BP cuffs to anyone.

title: Unbelievably buggy
text:
I can’t fathom how a software house could release such a horribly buggy piece of software as this. Each release is worse than the previous.  For example, I have a Withings Bluetooth blood pressure monitor. It worked flawlessly for years. For the past 6 months or so, it merely starts up and gives a puff and quits. I perform a hard reset on the cuff and repeat my disappointment.

The cuff has plenty of battery, responds over Bluetooth, it just barfs without doing much of anything, much less what I paid for. The app just seems to crash it since the Withings to Nokia handoff. Why???

And the curve fitting regression for weight etc is inexplicably lame. Please hire competent engineers.

title: Super ugly first time experience
text:
So I spent 20 (!) minutes just setting this smart scales up, and decided I can spend 5 more to write bad review.
At the beginning it was fine, and the app even detected the scales automatically. 
Then, I have to register with consent that the app would use my personal info. Well, strange...
The app does not provide a way to copy and paste password. You have to type!!! It is 2020, dear developer! Nobody types passwords.
Then, it asked me to provide my first name and last name. No, thanks. Birthday. Also, a big no. Height. OK, seems reasonable. And...
wait for it...
Weight!
I bought this smart scales to know my weight! Why should I provide it?
Then, permissions to Health data. The guide says: just turn everything ON. No, stupid app, I won’t! I have cheapest scales, they cannot calculate anything but weight related numbers. Why should I provide permissions to write my daily steps, for example?
Overall. Super dissatisfied.
The only thing that forced me to go through it is because I bought this thing already.

title: Great App and and scale only one complaint
text:
So I’ve had my scale for a couple years now and love being able to track my weight and get an idea of my weightlifting progress. 

My only complaint, BMI IS THE STUPID METRIC EVER! I’m 6’3, have a large frame, broad shoulders, long arms all the fun stuff. I’m sorry… actually I’m not sorry, if I drop below 215lbs I look gross and even my doctor is like, no no no go eat a cheese burger. On top of the fact, it doesn’t take into account what is muscle and what is fat… I’m not obese and really don’t like seeing that when I’m clearly not. Can you guys make it so the user can turn that feature off, when I was younger, that would have caused a lot more body image issues.

title: Perfect for me!
text: There are multiple reasons why I enjoy this app. It would probably be an exercise of redundancy to write all the details of this reasoning in this review, as many others have already posted reviews that state the obvious. It does exactly what I want it to do. Most users would, I suppose, find it helpful in attaining their particular health goals, by providing real data that allows the user to reflect and assess their progress toward their particular health goals! There are few things as valuable as having a point of reference in our quest for health, or for that matter any other goals we may have in life.

title: Missing the French
text:
Much like other users, I am missing the functionality of the original Withings app, that allowed for landscape view of BP data over the whole time series. I fell in love with the WiFi scale and have been tracking weight data for the whole family since early 2012. I own two BP meters that I have used to similarly track my BP data for medical reasons. That functionality is gone with the Health Mate app. Luckily I keep an 2nd gen iPad where the original Withings app still runs. 

This new app doesn't even launch in my backup iphone 4S.

Shame to Nokia for not grandfathering the better original features from the old French company....

title: New Update
text: So far so good on the update.  Registers faster with my iphone than before.  Just put it on, tap the button and the notification pops up on my phone and hit start.  New design seems easier on the eyes.  I was impressed when I bought this cuff so for now everything is working better than expected. Improvements—-..... maybe Siri type automation with verbal commands telling you to tap notification, app opens then asks you if you are ready to start and gives you verbal instructions about staying still, cuff level with your heart, proper placement etc.   Im just thinking of my golden years and what my home robot of the future would do.

title: Good overall
text: Have owned and used a few Withings products over the years. Happy to have quality choices from Withings when shopping for sports-health- type trackers. The company is always looking to advance user-friendly interfaces in the App. The only reason that I hesitate to rate the App five stars is because synchronization of products to Wi-fi often required exceptional patience for extended delays and/or a need to restart synchronization, but the App catches up as soon as pairing is successful. Still very happy with the Steel HR watches my husband and I wear daily and the App interface with our Withings scale is great for tracking and motivation.

title: Great app!!
text: Love this app!!  Very accurate. Took it with me to my cardiologist appointment to see if the readings were close to there’s and it was right on point! My cardiologist loves this app also. He loved how it showed and stored all my blood pressure readings and how it showed the amount of steps I have taken. He especially liked how it has a base over all reading of what the weekly readings were. I have never had any problems with this app and would recommend it to any one who has to constantly take there blood pressure and needs to have accurate readings. I also want to say I love the new updated version. Thanks again guys and great job! Keep up the good work!!

title: Wish it would share data with Apple Health app
text: After using this app for quite a few years and linking it with various fitness devices, the connection with Apple Health over six years has been spotty at best. I keep hoping it will improve. With every update they clean their connection with apple health has improved. Other health apps seem to be able to connect with Apple Health even when the app is closed. The health mate app won’t connect on a good day when both apps are open. I don’t know why they can’t get it right unless they just want to frustrate Apple users. I wish I had gotten another brand of scale. I’ve had two of their BP cuffs and neither worked very well. They are very difficult for a single person to put on properly, and of course have the same difficulty connecting to apple health through the Health Mate app.

title: Doesn’t support logging body temperature with apple’s HealthKit
text:
I use both a withings scale and the Thermo thermometer and I ran into a strange glitch where my new thermometer would only log temperature to withings healthmate application and not the Thermo app. I would actually have preferred it this way however the healthmate app does not seem to support logging body temperature into Apple’s HealthKit (HealthKit support is really the only reason I chose to go with the Thermo). 
To get around this I had to create a separate account to use with the Thermo app which fragmented my scale and thermometer data.

It doesn’t bother me too much but it would be a lot nicer to have everything in one application tied to one account.

title: Extremely disappointed...
text: I have been using this scale and app for a few years. It has always been a little finicky and clumsy to use. But I have had patience and persevered. Trying to get support for a problem is pretty much not going to happen. If you can find contact information (good luck - it’s buried- and for good reason) ‘cause they won’t email you back! I have all of a sudden started having a problem where it is adding a ‘weigh-in’ at 11:59pm every day and goes back to who knows when. This is an entry of what I am guessing is my current rolling average. I am also seeing entries for a few months at 11:59am that is a duplicate weigh in of my actual earlier that morning. This is wreaking havoc on my other apps that I use to analyze my weight changes. I am ready to throw this darn thing in the trash and go the old fashioned route.

title: So far not so good
text: Just purchased the wireless BPm and it’s not syncing at all. It’s confusing it doesn’t just work you have to play connect reconnect press buttons press more buttons then hopefully it will sync. Whoops nope not yet. Going to give this one more week and if it doesn’t start acting better it’s going back! As an industrial designer this thing should never have left the shop without it working, someone should have been demoted! what you think 18 year olds techno weenies are checking their blood pressure! I know what I am doing lord help anyone else! Just frustrating another product pushed out before it’s ready. They treat these things like apps. Oh it not working well we’ll get it fixed on the next round.

title: App almost always works, however monitor has issues.
text: I have the original Blood Pressure Monitor purchased from Apple when it was a Withings product. My only two complaints are this blood pressure monitor is geared for a small framed person and a small arm however people with smaller arms and small frames are not usually the ones that have blood pressure issues. My other complaint is occasionally it wants to stay turned on and the only way you can turn it off is to take the batteries out of the device that is soon as you put the batteries back in it turns back on again and the batteries eventually die.

title: Best Health App
text:
This is the best app I have ever used. Not only can you use the blood pressure cuff and the scale to automatically put your readings into the app but you can also put them in manually. It keeps track of your steps as well using your iPhone. It is one of those things that I would hate to live without. 
Another great feature is being able to send a report to your doctor or yourself so it can be taken to your doctor. 
You can see a graph or a list of your readings. It gives you many other things as well such as body fat. 
My hope is that a glucose monitor will be added to the devices offered.

title: Unreliable
text:
App looks smooth but does weird things all of the time. Best example—my BP Connect gave a few truly wild readings last week. I went to delete the BP readings and Health Mate would delete readings on either side of the one I wanted to delete. Sometimes it would delete the one I wanted, but more often than not I would lose days of good readings before knowing what it had actually deleted. Of course, there’s no way to get them back.

The app does integrate with Apple Health, which is a plus, but it doesn’t pull workout data from Health, just partner apps like Strava or MFP. Seems like if Withings wants to make Health Mate a one-stop app, it needs to broaden its data library.

Finally, my Body Cardio scale stopped working within 2 months of purchase. There was no way to troubleshoot within the app. I was just directed to their website. The app would keep trying to sync to a scale that wouldn’t power on.

BP Connect works okay, scale was great while it worked, but the app is frustrating if you need to change any of the data or want to integrate outside Withings small group of content partners.

title: Version 5.0.2
text:
After working fine for two weeks, this version started crashing on open although nothing was changed on my iPhone.  So I presume it’s some kind of server issue when the app tries to update logs from the cloud. Historically the app has worked perfectly for me.

UPDATE:  problem fixed with version 5.1.  App is now working well, as it did previously for my many years as a user. 

I would also like to mention that reviews should be posted here for the app, NOT for their products... which incidentally have also always worked well for me.

title: Overall I love it!
text: I got my withings to replace another popular brand of fitness tracker after it did 3 months into use. The biggest draw for me is I don’t have to charge it ( it runs off a basic watch battery) and looks more like a watch than a tracker. Ours were on sale at the time of purchase but we’re equal in price to the other brand. I’ve had it for four years now and have replaced the battery a couple of times and the band finally broke as well. My only complaint is that my mom now wants one and we can’t find them anywhere locally for her to compare and see which she wants. Wish our store where we got ours still carried them or that we could find them online.

title: App works great when not crashing
text: I got the Steel HR primarily to help track my workouts- there seems to be some issues with syncing to strava, because just about every other time I do a workout it fails to sync to strava and the app crashes. When this happens, the only way to get the app running again is to restart my phone (I have an iPhone 13, but this was happening on my iPhone X for awhile as well). I have tried uninstalling the app then reinstalling it and many other things, but this issue still exists. It is extremely frustrating to have to restart my phone just about every other day in order to track my runs. If this issue could be fixed, I’d consider this app to be very good but the regular crashing is a glaring problem.

title: Depends on product using
text:
Downloaded app to sync with the body+scale I purchased. Worked great at first. User friendly to setup but all the sudden one day stopped syncing with scale. Contacted support for the scale and very unhelpful. In the app when something doesn’t work it gives a very vague description and no help as to what to do. When you get to an error screen it just says try to stand closer to your router. Very little information for troubleshooting and again the “customer service” just says to reboot product as solution. After that no more ideas offered to help. 

Loved the app when it worked but the second it stops working it really stops working. Wish they had more information in the error messages and offered an option to send error codes so they could maybe try to help. But no such thing. 

Very frustrated and disappointed. (Sad face)

title: Withings watch vs Garmin
text:
I bought the Steel HR because I wanted a hybrid watch that didn’t need to be charged more than once a week. I had had an original Garmin Vivomove and was satisfied with it—I changed the battery every 12-18 months. Then it broke and I could t get the refurbished one to sync so I bought another Garmin. It was pretty but had to be charged every 24 hours and the hands on the watch face were just for show. 
I traded it in fir another Garmin that’s battery lasted longer but still had to charge it more than once a week (every 3-4 days). It was too inconvenient. 
people have complimented my new Withings Steel HR, not knowing it’s a smart watch—that’s the point! 😊 
The watch promises 20 days on a charge and seems to be on track to keep that promise. 
I like that the data syncs to the app regularly without me having to force a sync like I die with Garmin. It’s simpler than Garmin but just right since I’m active but not a world class athlete. 
It gives me basic and useful information about my mileage, HR and sleep. 👍🏼👍🏼

title: Provides timely & helpful feedback
text: Social scientists have known for years that when you track things it is much easier to improve them. I have used my Withins smart scale and BP cuff for years. During my use of these I have successfully lost 50 lbs and lowered my blood pressure. I am almost off of my very low dose of blood pressure meds. I find these tools helpful to keep me on track and informed so I can make good decisions for my health on a daily basis. Thank you Withins. I also used the baby monitor for years. It works great from anywhere in the world with WiFi. Grandparents in Britain can see their adorable grandchildren or it works as a nanny cam.

title: Great App
text:
I have read the previous review noting several issues, but I’ve been using my Withings Steele for 8 months and my Sleep device for 3 months with only a minor glitch - my results were reported in the wrong time zone. I emailed customer service and they had it fixed within 24 hours. I consider that great customer service!

Overall I really like my Withings watch. The results are timely, accurate, informative and it looks great. 

My only suggestion is to offer bands in different sizes. My band is very much too large.  Other than that, I highly recommend it!

title: Current app is awful
text: I hung on to the old app as long as possible, but it no longer works with iOS 14.5.  The new app is confusing and missing many features of the old app.  Hi/low weight history is missing under profile.  There is no longer a graph for blood pressure, so you have to look through each measurement one at a time.  Impossible to spot trends or issues.  There is no feed of measurements, only the dashboard.  If you sync your device in the morning you can’t see yesterday’s values and have to drill down into each item (steps, etc) to see them.  Extremely disappointed and even though I’ve invested quite a bit in various Withings devices it may be time to move on to something else because the app no longer provides the data in a usable format.

title: Are you kidding?
text:
Edit: In addition to below, which continues but less frequently, the biggest complaint I have is that I use a non-Withings step counter, but it appears to only accept a Withings watch or iPhone (steps counted by iPhone, not steps loaded into Health from outside the iPhone) as its data source. So this renders app less-useful to a FitBit user such as myself.

For the Aura, the app will periodically turn off your alarm, provide no notice, and simply offer a warning if you happen to open the app (as in, once you’ve overslept) that the alarm was disabled. How could they possibly build that in? How do they allow this? How are they clearly aware it can happen, but choose not to at least send an alert to your phone that your alarm is off?

It’s only a sensible thing if Withings/Nokia actively hate their customers. This is reasonable, since I now hate each of the idiots who work there.

Update: please don’t send me a request to contact your customer service that links to a generic help page; the details of my aggravation are above; read them, fix them

title: Personally I prefer the new look
text:
-Update-
The latest update seems to have fixed a lot of the issues I was encountering. Graphs and aggregated information now display correctly. They've also put back in the ability to see how you compare to what is considered normal and healthy for your demographic. There are a couple bugs here and there, but overall they've made some huge progress in what was honestly a really bad start. 

-Previoud Update-
Graphs for day/week/month hardly ever load correctly. It just spins as if it's attempting to retrieve the information. I want to view trends overall, not just the average for the current day. 

-Original-

I know a lot of people are complaining that the new color scheme is dull, but I actually find the app a lot easier to use with the new update. 

I would like to see some benchmarks added to the graphs though. It's nice to see where I'm trending overall, but the previous version allowed you to see what feel into the normal range for your demographic.

title: Get the basics right first
text:
To be fair, the steel HR watch and app convincing do a great job of combining "smart" features with something that still looks and feels like a real watch. Unfortunately, they fail at a few of the most basic capabilities you'd expect from a product like this. 

First, the time on the watch doesn't update automatically. I travel across time zones regularly, and my high tech watch can't even execute its most basic function (telling time) correctly. Syncing it is more complicated and time consuming than on my 50 year old mechanical watch. 

Second, dismissal of an incoming phone call or text is not replicated on the phone. What's the sense using the watch interface to pass on the call if the phone in your pocket won't stop ringing?

Third, text messages get cut off. I was thrilled when, after an app update, my Steel HR started displaying the full content of text messages. However, i was quickly made aware that the watch has a pretty low character limit, and ends up truncating a significant number of messages. This is a minor annoyance, but happens frequently enough to merit mention.

title: Dont waste your money on hardware,, app does not work
text:
I became a Withings customer over 2 years ago when I took a leap of faith and purchased their blood pressure monitor cuff. I was blow away by how good it worked and how easy it was to set up and use. So I gave the aura a try and once again I was impressed. Enough to give it 5 stars. However, they started pushing updates(dont know why since it worked just fine) and the pressure monitor started having issues, then the aura started having issues, the alarm stopped working properly(turning itself off or on) then the weight scale stopped reading body mass and also began having connectivity issues.

Their responses to other reviews have been ridiculous and typical big corporation mindset, (were sorry and we hope you buy something else in the future so we can rip you off again is pretty much what the last one said).

Its not rocket science, if you use the product, you can tell something is wrong with it. If you dont, then you should stop selling it! 
Im wondering if electronic sabotage is legal? Hmm. I might have to reach out to some media outlets and see what they think. Maybe 20/20 or 60 minutes.

title: I love this app!
text:
The app is innovative and thorough.  I do not mind sharing my info with them because I have nothing to hide and I want all the assistance offered. I do not mind if marketing is done on my behalf.  I am open to new and better products.  This app was presented to me through Platejoy.  My employer offered Platejoy and many other health support options to employees for free or covered by our employer provided health insurance plan.  I personally am very pleased with this app.  I do also appreciate the feedback both positive and negative from other users as it helps me to use my app and products in the most efficient way. 
mmlalk

title: Gorgeous Watch, Definitely Not Smart
text:
It magically tracks my sleep when it’s on the bed next to me instead of on my wrist. The app likes to keep me on my toes by randomly shutting off notifications when everything is updated and the app has stayed open. The calorie counter is totally whack and suggests that I burned 8 calories during a 50 minute workout. 
When I initially reached out to support, I outlined all steps that I’d taken already and included screenshots of my set up (showing notifications turned on for the phone and in the app and all of that) and in response I received a generic template saying to try exactly what I showed them I’ve already done. The watch is the most gorgeous watch out there, but extremely overpriced for what you get.

title: Please make trend line more accurate
text:
Hi! I've been using the app for years. I love the clean interface and intuitive controls, and I am super happy with my withings scale.

However, I have a request. Can you *please* change the way the trend line is calculated? I've started to notice that the line doesn't describe the data points very well. It can be extremely misleading and there's no option to turn it off.

When I looked at the app a few months ago, the trend line looked flat, suggesting that the workouts I was doing weren't having any effect. Now, I haven't been working out as much for various reasons, but the line makes it seem like I had lost so much weight during the previous period and gained a ton of weight since then. If I look at the data points, however, the distribution is pretty much the even so the line should be fairly flat.

Sure, I could definitely be more disciplined with working out consistently but it's very difficult not to be influenced by the ridiculous trendline every time I want to check my weight. :(

title: Pointless Product
text:
This is my 2nd scale. The 1st failed to restart after years of use which I kind of understood so I purchased a 2nd scale assuming the things we’ve all come to expect like syncing easily, managing multiple accounts etc would work seamlessly. 

It doesn’t sync. There’s no icon in the Ui to trigger a sync, there’s no information anywhere except for a weight that’s over 2 weeks old. How’s the weight get in the app from 2 weeks ago? I have no idea. 

If you install a widget on the new iOS, and you’re working towards a goal, don’t expect to feel like you’re making progress even though you are. The app displays old information. Ok so maybe it’s the widget. No I tap into the app and still no Ui or any way to update my weight other than manually inserting it. Ok you have an option to insert a number manually but you don’t add a refresh or sync icon here? It makes no sense. 

I’m returning this product for both horrible UX but because it appears the hardware is trash as well. 

Don’t waste your money on this “smart” scale. It’s 100% a waste of time and money. 

Seriously disappointed. This company has 1 job. And failed at the basics. And no I’m not hangry.

title: Don't need more fluff beyond smart scale sync
text:
I've been using this app and its predecessors for years to sync data from smart scale. (From way back when it was the Withings brand.)

To their credit, both the app and the scale have become more reliable syncing over time. That's great.

But in the recent major update, I've stopped getting notifications of my weigh-ins and I've started getting notifications from some health coach AI saying things like "Welcome to Health Mate!" and "Do you know your BMI?". Then when you open that up, there's just some generic health tutorial. I don't need that.

There's no clear way to disable the health coach messages and according to my notification settings I should still be receiving weight in notifications.

What is most annoying is that I didn't change anything other than letting the app update itself. I suspect the core user base of this app are those with a connected health device. This app should focus on that basic functionality first and make sure any additional fluff is optional and doesn't get in the way.

title: Health Mate rocks
text: I have used Withing scales for years, through a big multi-year weight loss of 60+ pounds, and these last couple years through an exercise obsession. The app continually improves to add new ways to share information with things like Apple Health and exercise. If it doesn’t do it now, just wait. It will get there. I don’t have to leave my 7 years of information behind switching apps. My new body analyzing scale breaks down tons of information, and using the app to watch muscle and bone density grow, while improving BMI and water is very satisfying and motivating.

title: Getting better but still buggy
text:
The app has got better since Withings re-acquired themselves from Nokia, but it’s still got issues (using it with the Steel HR, which I love):

The new interface for Running workouts, which is integrated with Runkeeper, looks great, except that most of the items within it, e.g. the pace and heart rate graphs, remain forever loading with a spinning wheel of death, even days later. If that’s fixed though it looks great!

Heart rate data still won’t export to apple health, and the measurement table shows nothing.

It doesn’t make any sense that one can plot the average heart rate over time, but not the sleeping heart rate, which is probably a more useful indicator to follow over time (as a decent proxy for resting heart rate).

Anyway it’s got the potential to be a great app, and I’m glad it’s being actively developed now! :)

PS: I love that Withings is shipping meaningful firmware updates to the Steel HR, including interface improvements! Would love to see a stopwatch/timer mode added...

title: A strong app and product offering from old school pros
text:
Nokia (now Withings for this product) has been making bleeding edge devices since back when Apple was only offering over-priced computer hardware that didn’t run at top speed. 

The infra and expertise this lends comes through in the Steel HR as well as the supporting app. It’s clean, functional, design-forward, and gets the job done without peripheral noise. 

If I had any feedback I’d ask that the app calibrate it’s motion data input in conjunction with local device motion processors. Over time, these adjustments would like create an even better activity profile.

title: Logging food and exercise
text: I think this app is great for men.  Works very well with my scale. Tracking muscle mass vs. Body fat is much more encouraging than just weight! My issue is that I am very lazy and would use the app much more to track if I can just plug in my workouts and food for a week. I don’t have time to go in every day but once a week would be most helpful. Example: weightlifting Monday, Wednesday and Friday for 30 m. Breakfast Oatmeal M,W,F and Eggs T,Th. Lunch Protein shake Monday through Friday. I like consistency in my meals and workout but logging daily is too much of a burden!  Thank you!

title: Poor interface
text:
The app interface is still totally nonintuitive. The old app had different colors for sleep vs weight vs steps so you could easily distinguish what you were looking at. Here everything is green and blue, no matter what you are looking it. I just tried to view sleep data by month and it’s a bunch of green and blue circles. What do they mean? Who knows! 

I also feel syncing with my watch takes much longer than it used to, to the point I barely bother opening the app anymore because I don’t have the patience to sit and wait for it to sync up. 

I also recently decided to give one of the little built in health programs a try (“better body”) only to get the error that it is “unavailable at this time.” I guess I shouldn’t have expected any better.

title: Poor interface for understanding weight
text:
The old Withings app that was replaced by this app was far superior in terms of understanding your weight trends. This version feels like it was done by a web developer with a sense of pretty design (it looks better at a quick glance than the Withings app), but with no understanding of numerical trends and no thought to making it good for its primary purpose. 

The vertical range is not scalable, the graphs slide around in funny ways that make it hard to look at where you want to focus, and the smoothed curve is not any sort of discernible sliding average but actually passes through the most recent weight, which creates a false trend. 

It would be great for someone who understands graphing trends to do a pass on this app. It went from being something I loved to an annoyance.

title: Easy To Use
text: I’ve been using the app on my iPhone since my wife purchased a Withing’s scale and it is easy to use and navigate. The syncing of data from Withing’s hardware with no interaction is greatly appreciated. Recently I installed Health Mate on my iPad and it works great. The larger clean interface makes checking in on daily results easier. I also really like the fact your app pull’s additional competitor’s data from Apple’s Health app. Just one request; I regularly use my iPad with Apple’s Magic Keyboard and would greatly appreciate a landscape view on the iPad.

title: Charlie
text: I have the scale and bp monitor as well as the steel he watch and I love them all. All five star items except the watch. I used to have the sapphire watch with the crystal face and when it broke I was sent the Nokia version which has a plastic face which is totally scratched up. I spent the extra money on the sapphire as I work construction and am hard on my watches. I don’t want to take it off while working as then it’s not tracking me half of the time I’m active. Now that withings has taken the company back I’d love to get my old watch back. Other than that the products and company have been amazing.

title: Keeps Getting Better
text:
So much better than it used to be.  It includes many more activities. I do a lot of pole walking (also known as Nordic walking), which burns more calories  than regular walking, so my stats would be more accurate if I could record it.  I would also  like aerial nice and gardening to be added.
I use two apps to measure steps.  Most days the two are in sync by just a couple of steps.  Others, not so much.  Today, this app shows 400 fewer steps than the other one.  Because of my activity today, I’m inclined to believe the other one is correct.
Overall, I like this app.

title: Great scale but the BMI rating is dangerous
text: I use this app with their smart scale and it’s actually a great scale but I have one major complaint for someone considering getting one. By default the scale displays the BMI which is actually offensive and borderline dangerous. I run 6-8 miles daily and have very little fat but I have broad shoulders and a large rib cage. So it tells me that I have a BMI of 26 based on my height which indicates I am overweight. I am definitely not overweight. BMI is a dangerous lie for people that have a poor self esteem and/or struggle with a anorexia. This setting should not only not be on by default but it should be removed altogether as an option.

title: Can’t delay the review and now fails
text:
So disappointed with this thing. It stopped uploading data with the update. I reconnected to my app and WiFi. I still get nothing to the app. 

I give any app that won’t let me suppress reviews a single star. I use it because it goes with my overpriced scale. The scale worked ok for a bit and now it changes its unit of measure every morning and it’s a pain to set back. It’d be easier to manually enter the info. It also is zeroing out at plus 4 pounds. I have to step on and off a few times to zero correctly. During this process it often takes the reading that is off. This app isn’t intuitive how to remove those extra readings so I have some crazy spiky graph of my progress. I’ve been manually moving data elsewhere to get a normal graph.

title: Amazingly informative, personalized. Interoperable with Apple Health and other.
text:
The increased interoperability with Apple Health and other devices are a blessing for older people who depend on various other devices, besides those from Withings.
The app has become increasingly my trusted source for key health data from weight to sleep data and much more. It integrates well with Apple Health on the iPhone and Apple Watch. An especially valuable feature is the increasing collection of personalized information snippets, almost as a trained human assistant in a virtualized office visit, quite amazing!
Henry Sinnreich

title: Excellent product
text:
I have been using Withings products for years. My all time favorite scale and watch. Unlike some other users, I find the scale easy to use and differentiate between close weight people. I have never had it to not work for me. The watch is superior to the iWatch for monitoring sleep and steps for me. I also have the BP monitor and it is simple to use. Many of my family members use my scale and BP monitor. 

I am very excited about the new watch that is coming out that monitors for a fib and will do an ekg. 

Keep up the excellent products.

title: Solid Program Which Also Motivates
text: I've been using the Health Mate app since I purchased a Withings scale about 4 years a ago. The app does a good job of tracking weight and "vitals". It has flexible views of trends - short, medium and long term timeframes - and has been very reliable in and of itself. Getting the Withings  scale to reliably connect to my WiFi network has been a problem but seems to be stable for the last few months ((early 2019). Surprisingly I enjoy the badges. I find them only slightly motivational, but very interesting factoids about places with which I'm often unfamiliar.

title: Withings+FitBit+MyNetDiary+iPhone 5s = Double Counting
text:
I used Withings for their scale (which is great) and to sync the scale's data to MyNetDiary.  I also sync steps/exercise to MyNetDiary via a FitBit One.  This combination worked well until Withings started tapping into the M7 processor on the iPhone 5s.  

The problem is that you cannot choose what information Withings syncs to other services like MyNetDiary. It's either all, or nothing.  The result is that MyNetDiary gets duplicate step counts/calories from Withings that are already recorded with a FitBit One.  Worse, Withings syncs 2 MONTHS worth of M7 data to MyNetDiary, which I had to manually delete.  

The bottom line is that I can no longer launch this app on the iPhone 5s without this happening.  A shame since I really liked this app :-(

I suspect we'll see more of this sort if thing as companies jockey to be the centerpiece in the health monitoring market. Hopefully Apple's HealthKit will fix these annoyances.

title: So bad it is useless
text: Since the last update made to the app, both the app and the Steel HR activity monitor are grossly inaccurate. Only about 30% of steps taken & distance covered register on the activity tracker and, when the app shows anything, it is data that relates neither to what is shown on the activity tracker nor the actual data. Customer Service support is pitiful- the email/chat support (I have been back and forth with it 5 times)  sends one through endless loop of these actions which dont fix the problem — have phone bluetooth forget the tracker, delete the app, reboot phone, factory reset of activity tracker. The phone number for customer support was disconnected, when I finally had the right phone number the person, who had trouble communicating in English, was rude and had no helpful suggestions.

title: New UI is a big step backward!
text:
Why the heck did some genius feel the need to change the way my weight curve is displayed?? Aside from the color change, which is less attractive and I can’t control, I can no longer pinch zoom to choose the length of time I want to focus on. Why on earth was is it a good investment of software resources to limit me to only a minimal set of options for time range -  month, quarter, etc, when I used to be able to check any duration I wanted??

Ironically I have been giving speeches in which I promoted the product by using screen captures of my weight story. The ironic thing is that I can no longer update these slides because the new UI is incompatible and I can no longer select the date range I wanted. Oh well, too bad for you.

title: More Data!
text: I just started using the app today, and I love it! I wish that I can export all data points, not just weight, into the health app. I use the health app as the center for, well, my health, and the fact that I paid $180 for a scale that can measure all that stuff makes it a bit disappointing that I can’t see all that data in the health app. Being an apple developer myself, I know that it’s not a hard implementation. Hope to see it soon in an update. If you need an intern to do this for you, just ask me! I’m sure I’m not the only one who’s been asking for this feature :)

title: Just getting started with the Nokia app but unimpressed
text: When inputting name or display scale name or trying to save the info through the app, I cannot press save and get the app to record the info. There’s a disconnect between where “save” is displayed on the screen and where the user needs to press to accomplish that task. It’s the first time I’ve noticed this kind of mismapping on an iOS app, and it’s not a good sign for this app’s quality. [Note: the developer wrote a response to this detailed feedback, directing me to the Nokia website to input the problem there. However, I’m not sure why he didn’t just make a note of the problem and put it on the list to be fixed after seeing my description here. Is it Nokia’s standard practice to give customers the runaround?]

title: App is more than adequate
text:
I’ve used multiple health apps prior and I find this app more than adequate for both non-athletes and athletes. 

I’ve looked at a few comments from the few disgruntled users and I don’t get it. I’m not sure what those folks expect from these types of apps but this one app isn’t supposed to have every type of measurement that exists but instead the measurements supporting the hardware they sell. 

It does partner with and integrate with most all health apps including walking, running, hiking and cycling. I’ve been pleased.

title: Great for tracking everything except actual steps...
text: I love my Withings watch and the app, particularly because I get a more accurate reading on the exercises I do versus FitBit. I also like how the watch automatically read what type of exercise I’m doing and starts tracking it. However, the daily step section is a bummer because it doesn’t count actual steps, but uses another method which results in a lower step count than you’d see on FitBit, the StepsApp, etc. Other than that annoyance, the app itself is a great way to track your progress on goals like weight, sleep, etc.

title: Terrible v5 update.
text:
I woke yesterday to find that my app was updated to v5 and boy was I surprised, just not in a good way!
I habitually step on the scale 3 times each time I weigh in to make certain I get a weight that is consistent and then delete 2 of those measurements.   Gone is any easy way to see the times that weight measurements were made.  I have to click like 3 times to get to the timeline.  The place that each measurement previously had the date and time, now only has the date!  Come on guys what’s up with that?

title: Finicky set up and busy cluttered nagging interface
text: I suppose if you need motivation from an app this one will do the trick but if what you’re really trying to do is just track your body measurements this app really gets in the way. It’s cluttered with a lot of extraneous information and material and the set up of the scale was extremely difficult. I think they are trying but it also is just too cluttered. Also, I rely heavily on voiceover and this app works very poorly with voiceover unfortunately. I also worry about the privacy of my data but I guess I should have been forewarned if I’m going to share this with a company other than Apple

title: Love my steel hr
text:
In the beginning had some issues with time hands drifting as power level dropped in battery (at 50% or less)and had to recalibrate frequently. Contacted customer service and they helped me immediately through emails. We tried some things, but came down to probably sending in to be replaced.  

I lived with it a little longer and Lo and behold whatever was stopping the hands from moving freely and keeping time freed up. Been flawless since then. 

Not sure if was sfw update or just took a bit to release the bind but awesome. 

Hr monitor has been pretty close to my norm, no complaints there. 

One thing is (not sure if is me or not) but steps count seems to vary day to day up or down by a good margin, even though weekdays I do much the same amount of steps, as my pattern is the same. ( maybe another sfw update can get this closer?). 

That is about the only thing I am not so happy with but overall still gets 5* approval

title: iOS 14.7.1 iPhone - Fixed!
text:
App works good!
I would like to make a suggestion.  Now when looking at the history, it defaults to all history when opened and if you want to look at the current month, you have to scroll through all the history to get to it.  If I change the view to month, it displays the first (oldest) month.  Not bad if you are just start using the app, but I have used the app for 3 years.  That’s a lot of scrolling.

App won’t open and stay open. Crashes. This is corrected.

title: It’s a good app but it’s missing a couple of things
text:
The team has added requested features over time and I do find the app to be great… on the iPhone. One of the easiest changes that could be made for iPad users like myself is landscape mode. I am baffled by how this is still not a thing. 

A big request from me that I haven’t seen implemented, but I think it would help frame better how people think about weight management, is setting a goal for body fat percentage and not just weight. This would be my ideal measurement to track as a goal within the app. 

Another thing that I would really appreciate they adding is Shortcuts support.

title: Good app but with glitches
text: Excellent app for what it is supposed to do. Love the badges, the data visualization, ability to edit sleep for when the watch messes up rarely. However, as other users pointed out, the interface rarely responds to device rotation and sometimes gets locked into a scroll position where the back button (and overflow menu) are no longer visible. I am still able to go back by using the swipe gesture but from comments I can see that most users don’t know about this. It would be great to have this fixed.

title: Love the old withings AP, Nokia destroyed it
text:
Update: today withings announced its buying back Nokia health. If your reading the reviews please get rid of this ap design, bring back the Withings version and make sure you don’t acquire any of the people who chose this terrible ap design. So glad you bought it back, now return it to being awesome and let Nokia disappear like the rotary phone did. 

Horrible App Update. It's absolutely amazing that Nokia would spend money to acquire a great company/app and then proceed to destroy it. No wonder Nokia is no longer in the mobile phone business.
